-LKWwhQdbZ7uNZ0ekDfI.article:
Do you have children or young people in your family? Do you want to spend time connecting with other families? Are you interested in supporting children and families develop in faith?

Join us for our parenting lunches after church on the second Sunday of each month.

We eat together, watch a short video to inspire us as we parent children in their faith, and share together ideas/epic fails/success stories of how God is and can use us to help our children grow in faith.

We are using brand new videos from Parenting for Faith to inspire us on our journey.

Bring some food to share. There will be toys and games available for children to play with (but please be aware that supervised childcare will not be provided and you will remain responsible for your own children).

These lunches are open to anyone who is interested in helping children and young people grow in their faith. We would especially love to see families coming along, whether you have done the Parenting for Faith course in the past or not – these lunches are for all of you!
-LKWwhQdbZ7uNZ0ekDfI.events_list_summary: Using the new Parenting for Faith videos

page_content.content: Gateway Church is a community of people committed to following Jesus and loving other people. Our church community is made up of people of all ages and from all walks of life. Words on a webpage can never give a true reflection of who we are, so we think the best way to get to know us is to come along on a Sunday then come to one of our monthly welcome lunches.

quotes.author: David
quotes.quote: I love Gateway. It's my family!

quotes.author: Jill
quotes.quote: My Lifegroup are the warmest, kindest people.

quotes.author: Karen
quotes.quote: I've been made to feel so welcome at Gateway.

-K1tJaoXK1LNZ-G24_f8.name: Who we are

page_content.content:
When new to a church, many people ask “Who are the leaders?”


At Gateway Caleb Ellwood leads a team of elders - Nathan Bulley, David Donkin and John Wilson.


Both Caleb and John serve as part of the church staff team.

Gateway Church relates to ChristCentral Churches, part of the worldwide Newfrontiers network of churches. The ChristCentral Team, led by Jeremy Simpkins, serves a growing number of churches and church plants across Britain and the nations.


Gateway Church subscribes to the Evangelical Alliance Statement of Faith.

Gateway Church is a working name of Gateway (York) CIO. Gateway (York) CIO is a charitable incorporated organisation registered in England and Wales, charity number 1165744. Our profile on the Charity Commission website can be found here.


Our Data Privacy Notice can be viewed here.


Principal Office: The Gateway Centre, Front Street, Acomb, YORK, YO24 3BZ, UK.

-K1tJaoXK1LNZ-G24_f8.summary_content:
Our first priority is to KNOW God - not just knowing things about him, but following him in a life-giving relationship and experiencing his empowering presence. 


God wants us to GROW in our faith, and he wants us to grow together as a church community. Both happen as we love and serve one another with the gifts he gives us. 


Becoming a disciple of Jesus changes our relationship with the world. God calls us to join him in his mission to GO and reach every person with the good news that Jesus is now King. Just as Jesus was sent into the world, he now sends us.
-K1tJaoXK1LNZ-G24_f8.summary_header: Our church community is made up of people of all ages and from all walks of life. We define our mission in three words: KNOWING, GROWING and GOING.

-K1tPhOFkVAecQlPSVrp.name: Sundays

page_content.content: We meet at the Gateway Centre every Sunday at 10:40am for worship and teaching for all ages. Refreshments are served from 10:15am in the cafe, before we spend time singing and worshipping together. Part way through the service the children and young people (up to the age of 16) head out to a full range of excellent children's groups, while the adults hear teaching and continue to worship together.
All our sermons are recorded and can be found on the Words page. Once a month we have a Welcome Lunch where we invite newcomers to the church to a lunch at a church family's home.

-K1tPhOFkVAecQlPSVrp.summary_content: At Gateway you will find that church is far more than a weekly gathering. Having said that, our Sunday morning worship service is the focal point of our church life and is our main weekly event.

-K1tPramR9kPSB4bscRW.name: Connecting In

page_content.content: We feel that one of the best ways for newcomers to get connected in to other people at Gateway Church is to come along to a Welcome Lunch. They are held monthly towards the end of the month, at various church members homes. They provide an opportunity to meet people and ask questions about Gateway. The next Welcome Lunch can be found on the Events page.

Lifegroups are small groups of 8-12 people meeting in people's homes across the city of York. Lifegroups form the backbone of our church community, enabling people to connect on a deeper level in a small group. We believe that transformation happens in the context of relationships, and Lifegroups are a great place to learn and grow together. Email office@gatewaychurch.co.uk if you're interested in joining one.

To help people communicate with one another, we have our own social media website called The City. If you have already set up an account, you can click through to it here and enter your username and password.


If you would like to join The City, please contact the office.

We are passionate about children and young people at Gateway. Our heart is to see children grow up with a genuine relationship with Jesus. We provide several activities and groups through the week for parents, children and young people. During our Sunday worship services we also cater for children and young people with age-specific groups. For enquiries about youth work contact Laura Crane, and for children's work contact Sarah Hogben.

Acomb Babies


A group for new parents in our local community to get to know one another.


Wednesdays 12:30-2:00pm.

Gateway Toddlers

A friendly, fun place for parents to bring their toddlers for free play and story time.


Wednesdays 9:30-11:00am.

Lights


A group for young people (school year 7 upwards) to explore more about what it means to follow Jesus. Games, worship, talks, groups, activities, trips out and more.


Fridays 7:00-9:00pm


For more information contact Laura Crane.

Sundays


As part of our weekly worship gathering we offer provision for children and young people up to the age of 16.


See the Info Point on Sundays for more details.

A friendly group for the over 65s offering hot drinks and snacks and a place for people to meet together for friendship and fellowship.


Fridays 10:00am-12:00pm

Connect, an informal gathering hosted by Caleb Ellwood, is an opportunity to learn more about Gateway's distinctives as a church family and hear about how to become a Member of Gateway Church.


Details of the next Connect can be found in the Events section.

-K1tPramR9kPSB4bscRW.summary_content: Throughout the Bible we see the church described in all kinds of word pictures. Each one speaks of connectedness and relationship. At Gateway we are passionate about people connecting with one another and encouraging one another. Whatever your life stage, we want to help you discover God's best for you.

-K1tQ0jUydotRM_j2uLI.name: Serving the Community

page_content.content: The Gateway Centre provides a context for much of our work with the community. The Centre is available for hire to local groups - contact Wendy Neary for more details.

A group for new parents in our local community to get to know one another.


Wednesdays 12:30-2:00pm.

A friendly, fun place for parents to bring their toddlers for free play and story time.


Wednesdays 9:30-11:00am.

We partner with the award-winning national charity Christians Against Poverty (CAP) to deliver a free debt advice service to those struggling with unmanageable debt. Our Debt Coaches, Jackie Adie and Lucy den Braber, work with individuals and families to support them out of debt. For more information you can visit the CAP website or call 0800 328 0006.
On a Monday we run distribution sessions in partnership with York Foodbank, offering people in crisis 3 days of emergency food and a chance to talk and pray with one of our volunteers.

Several partner agencies run services and projects from the Gateway Centre.


They include York Foodbank, Reflect Pregnancy Support, Dayspring Counselling, Restore York, Tiny Toes Music and Alcoholics Anonymous.

-K1tQ0jUydotRM_j2uLI.summary_content: From the Gateway Centre we run several services for the benefit of the wider community.

-K2E6rEUJFHg3fBuzqXP.description: I'm married to the lovely Rhona and live locally in Acomb. We have three children - Emma, Micah and Maisie, and if you can't find me at the Gateway Centre you'll find me riding my bike, working on my allotment or watching American TV box sets! I lead the Gateway eldership team and work full-time for the church.
-K2E6rEUJFHg3fBuzqXP.name: Caleb Ellwood

-K4DJBpZLZphvfDpHB46.description: I’m married to Pam and we have three grown-up children and (at the last count) four grandkids. I have the privilege of being part of the Gateway eldership team and preach regularly. I enjoy getting out in the country walking, cooking for friends and most kinds of roots music (blues, folk). Bliss is sitting down on a rare evening with a good crime thriller and a drop of malt.
-K4DJBpZLZphvfDpHB46.name: John Wilson

-K69IG6QUmdEhaa2d8cD.description: I am married to Simon (whose willingness to listen to me is second to none!) and have two amazing teenage daughters, Jess and Rachel. I work as the Centre Manager at Gateway, and take care of the finances of the Church, ably supported by Karen Donkin. This involves a wide variety of roles, tasks and interactions making for a busy, sometimes bizarre, but wonderful working life. I am so grateful to have found such a sense of belonging and fulfilment as part of the Gateway Church family.
-K69IG6QUmdEhaa2d8cD.name: Wendy Neary

-K69IonGnC8F9m783iYU.description: Trev & I moved up from Birmingham to be a part of this church in 1984, we have 5 grown up children and enjoy spending time with them and our 8 grandchildren usually involving food! I have worked for our church since 1997 and since 2002 have been the CAP centre manager, a role I love as it enables me to offer practical help and support to people in our community showing them that we and God care about them.
-K69IonGnC8F9m783iYU.name: Jackie Adie

-K69JubYqTCKhfeYjJvW.description:
I am married to Karen and we have two boys who have both flown the nest.

I have the privilege of being on the eldership team at Gateway and am a Trustee with responsibility for Church Finances.

I am a Chartered Surveyor and work in Hull for a property investment and development company

In my spare time I like to keep fit and am particularly keen on cycling at the moment.
-K69JubYqTCKhfeYjJvW.name: David Donkin

-K69N9rXPn_l8OlXW_UZ.description: I am the father of Leah, Sarah and Jessica and husband of Rachael. I've been a teacher for far too long, but remain passionate about my favourite subjects: history and politics. Combined with my involvement in church, that probably amounts to three topics never to bring up at dinner parties. I enjoy reading and photography as well as the occasional data-related spreadsheet.
-K69N9rXPn_l8OlXW_UZ.name: Nathan Bulley

-K69Nq65ozFVY4kRrJIf.description:
I’m married to the wonderful Nina, and we have 3 small & energetic children, Rachel, Hannah & Nathanael. Originally from Plymouth, I grew up in missions travelling the world.

I have a degree in theology & have a passion for teaching the Bible. I’m also a big sports fanatic & love movies (especially Star Wars).

At Gateway I lead a Lifegroup and I also oversee the church’s football team, Acomb Gateway FC, alongside serving on the committee for the league.
-K69Nq65ozFVY4kRrJIf.name: Peter Sloan
-K69Nq65ozFVY4kRrJIf.title__role: Lifegroup Leader, Cluster Leader & Football Team Manager

-K69OLy9I_lywUPur6Qm.description:
I gave my life to Jesus as a child and have had many adventures with him ever since, and can't imagine an existence without Him. I am passionate about mission, both abroad and locally, and also building the local church where I love being involved in a variety of ways. I have fun helping and teaching the youth, as well as caring for people under the umbrella of "Parish Nursing" and as part of the pastoral care team. I also oversee the Gateway Foodbank and am team leader of Oasis, Gateway's community for over 65s.

I am enjoying retirement after approx 45 years in NHS and loving the new opportunities for mission that God is giving me. I also love skiing, badminton, dabbling with my art class, and having coffee with friends.
-K69OLy9I_lywUPur6Qm.name: Faith Turner
-K69OLy9I_lywUPur6Qm.title__role: Pastoral Coordinator, Foodbank Coordinator and Oasis Team Leader

-K7l1lXuYOP0cui-f4OG.description:
Jeanne & I married in 1980 and have two grown up successful children. Family welfare is important to me and I consider family life to be at the core of happiness. I continue life’s journey to love God, Life and People, I am better at this some days than others.

We lead the Welcome Team striving to create a warm & friendly welcome when you visit Gateway Church.
-K7l1lXuYOP0cui-f4OG.name: Gary Dickinson

-K7l2hJhoo03XWmHdMCV.description:
During a difficult period in 1990, I needed answers, so started searching eventually finding what I’d been looking for at “One Voice” in October 1992. Getting to know God did not magically take away or prevent problems but gives me strength and hope through them.

I work in the community as a carer and at Gateway I’m part of the “Welcome” team. I’m happy to share my life experiences in order to encourage others.

I am married to Gary with a son and daughter.
-K7l2hJhoo03XWmHdMCV.name: Jeanne Dickinson

-K7l5kdmYH26XAJF769J.description:
I'm from Dorset but have lived in York for 9 years now and love it here.Our little boy Peter has a great Dorset-Yorkshire fusion accent going on! I'm married to Steve who you'll most likely hear drumming on a Sunday. I work part time as a Speech and Language Therapist at York Hospital.

At Gateway I help out as one of the Lifegroup leaders.I would say my favourite thing would be sitting in bed with tea, toast and a good book!
-K7l5kdmYH26XAJF769J.name: Hannah Racher

-K7l7fbkH9clACi7BlEe.description: I am Rosemary Davis and am married to George. We have 2 lovely daughters and 4 fab grandchildren. I can be found at the Oasis Cafe on a Friday morning serving tea and coffee with lots of chatter. I am also looking forward to being part of the welcome team. I love gardening, reading and knitting and in my spare time I'm usually doing one of these; though I can sometimes manage the reading and knitting together.
-K7l7fbkH9clACi7BlEe.name: Rosemary Davis

-K7l9WVuPKl9FQoWCq5s.description: I’m George Davis, married to Rosemary. I have 2 grown-up daughters and 4 grandchildren. I play golf two or three times a week, weather permitting, and also fly on my flight simulator on my computer. Together with Rosemary I run the Oasis over 60s café at Gateway on Friday mornings. My desire for those who come to Oasis is to see relationships develop and for them to experience the love of Jesus. I am also part of the Gateway welcome team.
-K7l9WVuPKl9FQoWCq5s.name: George Davis

-K7lBAE_u6MX9HrQOiNU.description:
I am Jean and am married to Billy, and we lead a Lifegroup together. I am also involved in working with the younger children on Sundays in the Explorers group. I work full time as an Independent Financial Adviser.

We have lived in York since 2008 and came here when we moved back to live in the UK after living in the States. Our son and daughter in law had been part of Gateway when they lived on the RAF base at Linton and they love coming to visit us as they get a chance to catch up with friends here, as well as us.
-K7lBAE_u6MX9HrQOiNU.name: Jean Geraghty

-K7lH5gFkAvQK8Gg_5Or.description: I am married to Al and together we have two teenage children, Tom and Annie; we live in Acomb. I love my job as a primary school teacher in York, and in my spare time enjoy cooking, reading and running. Al and I lead a Lifegroup.
-K7lH5gFkAvQK8Gg_5Or.name: Steph Gee

-K7lHp34_NRRnZbEU-Yk.description: I am husband to Steph and dad to Tom and Annie, and work for an electronics company in Saltaire, near Bradford. Steph and I lead a Lifegroup together. As a charity, Gateway has a team of trustees of which I am the Chair. In my spare time I love reading and catching up on old Doctor Who episodes on telly.
-K7lHp34_NRRnZbEU-Yk.name: Alan Gee
-K7lHp34_NRRnZbEU-Yk.title__role: Lifegroup Leader, Cluster Leader and Chair of Trustees

-K7lImW9bWKw30oAxHFD.description:
I’m Mark and I'm a Trustee of Gateway Church (that’s the legal Charity Commission bit of things). I'm married to Georgina and we have 3 grown up children and 2 grandchildren, who think my camera is a part of me!

I work in York for Aviva, and spend a lot of my “spare” time running! But I’m built for comfort, not for speed. I’ve also got a practical streak, and have been known to do a bit of gardening and DIY.
-K7lImW9bWKw30oAxHFD.name: Mark Howard

-K7lJbahrSn3zwOVuqOw.description: I’m Georgina. I am married to Mark I have 3 grown up children – one daughter, two sons and two daughters-in-law, and one adorable grandson. I co-lead a LifeGroup, and I’ve been a member of Gateway Church for 28 years. In my spare time I enjoy eating cake and drinking coffee, and getting to know to people. For exercise I swim and run. I also enjoy cooking within Gateway, and have worked in Gateway café until recently.
-K7lJbahrSn3zwOVuqOw.name: Georgina Howard

-K7lL7QSoy3fiwKfBwC2.description: I am blessed to be married to Nancy. I am an independent music tutor in York, teaching children and adults through the week. I love the Bible and theology, and enjoy geeky discussions about topics with long Latin words. At Gateway I serve on the prayer team on Sunday mornings. Nancy and I also lead a Lifegroup.
-K7lL7QSoy3fiwKfBwC2.name: Joe O'Neill

-K7lLxbfoGg3Nj-GZsr-.description: I am married to the wonderful Joe. We live in Clifton and moved to York from Brighton in 2014. I am a doctor currently training to be a GP. I love spending time with my family and friends and force myself to go to the gym. Joe and I lead a Lifegroup. I run the info point desk which is where you can find all the information about activities going on in the church. I also help with kids work and am really passionate about women’s ministries.
-K7lLxbfoGg3Nj-GZsr-.name: Nancy O'Neill
-K7lLxbfoGg3Nj-GZsr-.title__role: Lifegroup Leader and Info Point Team Leader

-K7lNZAYyC4RYVSYSE2e.description:
Married to Helen, with four children, youngest of whom is Bethany.

Eleven grandchildren, only three in York.

I am a trustee.

We’ve been members since the very beginning of the fellowship.

Interesting fact - the church met in our house during the second year of its existence back in the early 1980’s, until numbers exceeded thirty.
-K7lNZAYyC4RYVSYSE2e.name: Manton Dumville

-K8Ui8BzHFarxltxkYDq.description: I am married to Peter and together we have three beautiful children, Rachel, Hannah and Nathanael. I am currently in the middle of training part time to become a GP and enjoy the mix of working and looking after my family. Within Gateway I lead a Lifegroup with my husband. On Sundays you might find me on the worship team or working with the older primary aged children. Midweek I also help with Gateway Toddlers and the Oasis cafe.
-K8Ui8BzHFarxltxkYDq.name: Nina Sloan

-K8Uj83GQGz7aHuujHCV.description: You'll most likely find me behind the drums on a Sunday morning! I'm one of the Lifegroup leaders at Gateway. During the week I work in Leeds as an Environmental Consultant. My wife Hannah and I have lived in Acomb for about 6 years now. We have a little boy of 4 1/2 called Peter who is full of beans and keeps us busy, and we are expecting baby no. 2 in March.
-K8Uj83GQGz7aHuujHCV.name: Steve Racher

-K8sTPqfsE2yrZw-NLl7.description: I am married to Jamie and have two beautiful kids, Reuben and Lily. On a Sunday morning you will often find me chasing after them and helping in the Adventurers kids group.I also help with the coordination of Lifegroups, and along with Jamie also lead a Lifegroup of our own. I work part-time as an English as a foreign language teacher and look after my kids the rest of the time. I love meeting up with other mums and their little ones, cooking (and sharing it with others) and on the rare occasion when I have a bit of time to myself, reading a book or peruse recipes.
-K8sTPqfsE2yrZw-NLl7.name: Reni Holliday

-K8sTtwFKXKL4Es6d5i-.description: I am the husband of the wonderful Reni, and father to two brilliant kids: Reuben and Lily. I help with the coordination of Lifegroups, and along with Reni also lead a Lifegroup of our own. On Sunday mornings I'm often to be found helping the toddlers make a spectacular mess in the Discoverers group. I love sport and enjoy playing for a local cricket team. I work as an accountant, which is really interesting, no really. Wait, come back...
-K8sTtwFKXKL4Es6d5i-.name: Jamie Holliday

-K9CqKZtipqARvpgN6_L.description: I love being a part of Gateway Church and I believe our children Jonathan and Gabriela are privileged to be growing up in this environment. I am married to Josue who I met when a missionary in Guatemala (he now also goes by the name Dominic as easier to pronounce). You will often see me playing the keys in the worship group which I love doing! I also run a Christian charity called Acts 435.
-K9CqKZtipqARvpgN6_L.name: Jenny Herrera

-K9Ct6LGZeY9tIJBTRdK.description: I've been part of Gateway my whole life, and absolutely love it! I’m married to Dan and we have 3 children who treat Gateway like their second home! I love all things creative, and am never happier than when out in the fresh air with my family and our dog. At Gateway I am involved in kids work, leading the worship team, preaching, and helping out in the office (when I’m not busy with the little people at home!)
-K9Ct6LGZeY9tIJBTRdK.name: Bethany Wheeler
-K9Ct6LGZeY9tIJBTRdK.title__role: Worship Team Leader and Preaching Team

-K9CuogGFOsRfxJxqW89.description: I'm Rachael, mum of the Bulley clan. Married to Nathan, we have 3 gorgeous primary school aged girls. At Gateway I'm involved in preaching, and I love how sharing stories can encourage and challenge us. Outside of church you'll find me spending time with my family or watching American TV dramas.
-K9CuogGFOsRfxJxqW89.name: Rachael Bulley

-K9CwAJI9T7lilGVDVhU.description: I've been part of Gateway for over 10 years since I moved to York and married Bethany. We have 3 children and a dog, so for a break (!) I go to work as an accountant in Leeds. I am on the Gateway preaching team and lead the Worship Team. I love to watch and talk about any sport and am a lifelong Swindon Town football fan.
-K9CwAJI9T7lilGVDVhU.name: Dan Wheeler
-K9CwAJI9T7lilGVDVhU.title__role: Worship Team Leader and Preaching Team

-K9DA1dCuAwO5UrbEBaR.description:
I am married to Wendy with two lovely teenage daughters. I am an RE teacher in a North Yorkshire secondary school.

I love music, photography, cooking, the Lake District and my family, but not necessarily in that order!
-K9DA1dCuAwO5UrbEBaR.name: Simon Neary

-K9DEdH8MS788BsbbSr3.description:
I’m Neville. I am blessed & honoured to be married to Karen. Together we lead a life group on a Wednesday evening. I also have the privilege of being on the prayer team and the welcome team, and occasionally I preach at Gateway.

I have a passion for evangelism and this has taken me off to Malawi on 10 occasions so far, where along with a team of people we work with local churches to reach out to people who do not yet know Jesus.

Family is very important to me and I have recently become a Grandad.
-K9DEdH8MS788BsbbSr3.name: Neville Croucher

-K9RlOpKXcU8GgA_-TLU.description: Hi my name is Katie and I've been a member of Gateway church since 2006. I'm married to Ben and we have three boys - Jacob, Zach and Caleb. Ben and I run a Lifegroup together, and I help out at Gateway Toddlers on a Wednesday morning. At the moment I'm mainly a full-time Mum but I also work a few hours a week for Acts 435 - an online direct needs charity. At the weekend I love spending time as a family - baking, going on days out and relaxing!
-K9RlOpKXcU8GgA_-TLU.name: Katie Greene

-K9RmHlpxCW2fonjEcAt.description: Hi my name is Sarah and I work part time at Gateway leading our wonderful kids team. I live with my husband Alistair and our two lovely children in Acomb. As a mum of 2 young children I spend most of my time at toddler groups or on the floor playing with toys! I love searching on Pinterest for new ideas and activities to do with the kids at home or at church, and especially love anything involving glitter, gloop or any other colourful mess!
-K9RmHlpxCW2fonjEcAt.name: Sarah Hogben

-K9RofoVv8czQec5en3G.description:
I'm a retired health visitor born and bred in Acomb. Two days a week I look after my two squabbling grandaughters in Bingley.

At Gateway I run Acomb Babies, a group for new parents. It's great to watch people make new friends and grow in confidence.

I am also deputy safeguarding coordinator for Gateway, not much fun but neccessary.

In between times I enjoy keeping up with old friends and new, hanging out in City Screen, eating cake, sewing and thinking about riding my bike and swimming.
-K9RofoVv8czQec5en3G.name: Joan Linley

-K9RsZG5NCAZ5DSJAdo-.description:
I have been coming to Gateway Church with my wife Sue for almost 30 years. We have two adult sons and in recent years we have worked with Family Matters York to help support couples with their relationships.

To earn a living I work for a large York based Construction and Manufacturing business.

At Gateway I head up the Stewarding Teams on a Sunday morning and my aim is to ensure that everyone has a safe and welcoming environment in which to worship God.
-K9RsZG5NCAZ5DSJAdo-.name: Dave Coward

-K9Rsxx7NcAt9vyWlCLy.description: Hi! My name is Louise, I'm involved in the prayer team and I help lead a women's life group with Bridget. I first came to Gateway when I moved to York, nearly 20 years ago, to do my teacher training. I now teach languages in a local secondary school. I love spending time with family and friends and definitely champion the coffee shop industry in York!
-K9Rsxx7NcAt9vyWlCLy.name: Louise Manning

-K9Rt_MpZuRpKKXM2Bh6.description: I am married to the wonderful Paul Betts and together we have two beautiful daughters. We live in Acomb. I lead worship at Gateway Church and play/sing in the worship band, serving alongside an awesome team of worshippers and musicians. My passion is music, and when I'm not at the Gateway Centre, I work as a freelance musician and teacher in the community, at home and in schools.
-K9Rt_MpZuRpKKXM2Bh6.name: Nicola Betts

-K9RuaSrsOyKMHwUps9P.description: I am married with four grown up children but no grandchildren yet! At Gateway I have been leading a women’s life group (together with Louise Manning), and I also help with Alpha and teach the New Start course. I am passionate about getting new Christians ‘planted’ in the church and about supporting persecuted Christians in other countries (by praying and writing them letters). Otherwise I work full time as an administrator at York University and enjoy sewing, art, walking and vegetable gardening.
-K9RuaSrsOyKMHwUps9P.name: Bridget Hunt

-K9RvL5E5rYBfn_BNALy.description: I am married to David, mum to Scott and Jonny and mother-in-law to Alex. I have lived in Acomb and have been part of Gateway for many years and LOVE this church! I work one day a week in the office, mainly with finances and stuff relating to the Centre. On Sundays I can sometimes be found serving refreshments or manning the Info desk. I also work part time in a local college, and when I'm not doing any of the above I enjoy reading, films and a good natter over a cuppa.
-K9RvL5E5rYBfn_BNALy.name: Karen Donkin

-K9RvnEphavncCqnYmps.description: I moved from Glasgow to York in 1980 and was involved in the prayer fellowship that became a church that is now known as Gateway. I have been married to Jill for over 34 years and have two grown-up children and three grandchildren. I work as a data analyst but my heart is for people rather than figures. Jill and I lead the prayer team and are responsible for marriage ministries in Gateway. We are also part of the Couples in Crisis team working with Family Matters York.
-K9RvnEphavncCqnYmps.name: Tom Ross

-K9XR8PlqFVKc_d1aPjx.description: I'm married to the lovely Jean and have one son, Martin and two grandchildren, Matthew and Charlotte. I am a qualified British Cycling Level 3 coach so you’ll find me over at York Sports Village coaching kids cycling #cliftonfastkids. Jean and I lead one of Gateway’s Lifegroups and we are privileged to be involved with a great bunch of people in the group.
-K9XR8PlqFVKc_d1aPjx.name: Billy Geraghty

-K9XRXOtj2lH1o9yUPyl.description: I’m married with two grown up daughters, 3 cats, and a tank of tropical fish. I’ve been a member of Gateway since 1990. You will often find me serving tea and coffee on a Sunday morning. I have the privilege of leading the new day time Lifegroup and being part of the team teaching the Sunday morning teenage group. I enjoy gardening and reading when I am not looking after my menagerie or working.
-K9XRXOtj2lH1o9yUPyl.name: Judith Summerfield

-K9YteCoCvE4vhOTVe1j.description:
I am married to Tom and help lead prayer and marriage ministry in the Church. We have two children and three grandchildren.

I am a Health Improvement Specialist with City of York Council and have a private Counselling Practice. l volunteer with two Christian charities in the city, as a trainer and supervisor with Reflect Pregnancy choices and loss service, and as a trustee for Family Matters where Tom and l are also part of the couples in crisis team. I love supporting couples and individuals to work through issues to become happier and healthier, and also reading and relaxing with friends and playing with my gorgeous grandchildren.
-K9YteCoCvE4vhOTVe1j.name: Jill Ross

-K9YvZLHB9hQF5dBqyHR.description: I'm Simon, and at Gateway I'm involved in the music ministry and the occasional preach as well. As I'm a teacher by trade, I have a real passion for seeing the teachings of Jesus applied to our lives. You'll often see me at the front with my guitar, and I'm excited by the way God is moving through our worship of Him. When I'm not at Gateway, I'm usually cycling or hanging out with friends.
-K9YvZLHB9hQF5dBqyHR.name: Simon Desborough

-K9bWX98DDFkx0kWLb2c.description: I'm from the beautiful city of Edinburgh, but moved to York to marry the wonderful Caleb. I am very grateful that that move brought me into the incredible Gateway Church family! Our eldest daughter, Emma, and young twins, Micah and Maisie, keep me pretty busy, but I also work part time for a wonderful charity called Acts 435 (www.acts435.org.uk), which serves to "crowdfund" the practical needs of people in poverty.
-K9bWX98DDFkx0kWLb2c.name: Rhona Ellwood

-K9lOANxpy58wuuBttad.description: I grew up in Belfast but at age 18 went to study in Edinburgh, where I met my husband John. We’ve lived in York since 1983 and have 3 grown up children - two sons and a daughter - and four grandchildren. I also get involved in various church-related activities alongside John in his role as elder. I love to see people finding their place in Gateway and encouraged to use their gifts. My hobbies include swimming, walking and opera and I love to travel.
-K9lOANxpy58wuuBttad.name: Pam Wilson

-K9lOhc87hfEPSC95LZP.description: I'm married to Ellen we live with our 3 fast growing boys near the old Terry's chocolate factory. I work at Christians Against Poverty in Bradford, which was a dream job for me.. it was the main thing that prompted our family move up from London. I'm now the only southerner in a house of northerners! As a family we really enjoy people... our ideal is having a house full of diverse people relaxing, having fun, eating together and developing friendships.
-K9lOhc87hfEPSC95LZP.name: Jon Day

-KM-o8oi_qtPe35wWrrj.description: I’ve been part of Gateway for more than 20 years, but spent 11 of those years working in Asia for a mission organisation. Now back in York, I’m delighted to be able to serve as administrator in the Gateway office. You’ll also sometimes find me manning the Info Point on Sundays. I enjoy spending time with people from other countries and I regularly help at the Monday night international cafe in the Spurriergate Centre here in York.
-KM-o8oi_qtPe35wWrrj.name: Christine Hobson

-KO4T3gIPaN7pg8yFzu7.description: Tony and his wife Kay are friends of Gateway and are based at City Church Dundee
-KO4T3gIPaN7pg8yFzu7.name: Tony Smith

-KQ0I_J3_mZI0zdWFMe-.description:
I have been attending Gateway for just over four years with my parents and live in Acomb, quite close to the centre.

My role is to look after the Gateway Centre in terms of maintaining the building and contents. Basically, if there’s a light out or something needs repairing, it’s me you would look for!

I’m also very privileged to serve in various roles in our vibrant Children’s and Youth work teams. In the last three years I have learnt to play guitar and this comes in handy for leading the 5-10s in worship now and again and for our regular Youth worship band.

I am also a keen gardener and love ‘golden age’ films from the 1930s-1960s especially Westerns.
-KQ0I_J3_mZI0zdWFMe-.name: George Jennison

-KQ0JVApGX6LmE05tJ4C.description:
I’m Karen, my lovely hub is Neville, together we are hub & wifi. Oh dear, his humour is rubbing off on me! We have 5 grown up children between us & at the moment 1 gorgeous granddaughter. We have lived in Acomb for over 6 years. We are both on the welcome team and we lead a Lifegroup on a Wednesday evening. For me this means orchestrating a group of people & hearing what they have to say on living with God in their lives.

I work from home but am happy to be interrupted if anyone wants to call for a cuppa. I love the sunshine & I’m a fair-weather gardener. Watching the garden grow is my speciality!
-KQ0JVApGX6LmE05tJ4C.name: Karen Croucher

-KQfanEczLOkVqK_nBgU.description: I’m Ben and I’ve been at Gateway since 2006 after marrying Katie and coming to York to study at York University. Together we are kept busy looking after our 3 boys: Jacob, Zach and Caleb. In my spare time I work as a primary school teacher in the Early Years and love working with families and children at Gateway Church. I also enjoy getting out into the garden, walking, reading and drinking the occasional single malt whisky. I also lead a Life Group with Katie.
-KQfanEczLOkVqK_nBgU.name: Ben Greene

-KagrFtUShXah13bxu5a.description: I moved to York in 2008 when I married Sarah. We now have two brilliant children, Josiah and Eliana, to complement our often busy and crazy home! As part of the church I am passionate about seeing people meet with God in worship and am part of the amazing team here at Gateway who help that to happen. When I am not doing that, I work for a high end property company and enjoy a host of hobbies, from cycling to board games!
-KagrFtUShXah13bxu5a.name: Ali Hogben

-Klxszm7gqS6ht6waH0w.description: My name is Laura Crane, I am the Youth Team Leader here at Gateway Church. I am married to the amazing Pete Crane and we have two gorgeous little children called Joel and Hope. We moved to York from London in August 2016; in London I worked for a Christian organisation called Youth for Christ. One of the things I love most about the youth at Gateway is First Friday Food, where once a month we cook and eat a meal together, as it combines two of the things I enjoy the most - food and chatting!
-Klxszm7gqS6ht6waH0w.name: Laura Crane

-KtLrnkc97Uoo8tGx8cX.description: I'm Margie, I'm married to Nick and we have three grown up children and 2 grandchildren. Nick and I joined Gateway in 2014 after moving to York from St Albans in search of adventure. We live in Naburn by the river (yes, we get flooded!) where we run a B&B. In my spare time I volunteer at the food bank and also for the National Trust. Together Nick and I lead a life group which is wonderfully hosted by Ian and Bev Wright.
-KtLrnkc97Uoo8tGx8cX.name: Margie Lee

-KtM-o3vOvQk-yC_6qmo.description: I'm Nick, married to Margie, and part of Gateway church since 2014 when we moved to York. I spent most of my career as an accountant in the charity sector, with a stint at Joseph Rowntree here in York. I'm now working on developing a smallholding and wildlife site, and we run a B&B as well. If I could, I'd spend most days on the river just pottering about. We are privileged to lead a life group where we aim to learn together, hear from God and encourage and pray for each other.
-KtM-o3vOvQk-yC_6qmo.name: Nick Lee

-KtM2LZ1s9DQSU5T4bwX.description: I am originally from Guatemala in Central America. I moved to the UK in 2009 with my British wife Jenny and we have been happily settled in York ever since. I changed my name to Dominic to make it easier for people to pronounce. At Gateway you'll hear me called by either and that's fine! I love spending quality time with my children Jonathan and Gabriela.
-KtM2LZ1s9DQSU5T4bwX.name: Dominic Josue Herrera

-KtM5DZ1uRn8qnEoUHJu.description: Hi my name is Rob, I live in the city centre, but have been a part of Gateway for many years. I'm on the leadership team of the music ministry and head up the AV side of things. I love being part of the Gateway family. I find purpose serving on team and worshipping as part of the band. My main passion is music and I think we have a great set up at church. Outside of church I enjoy sports, music, and Game of Thrones!
-KtM5DZ1uRn8qnEoUHJu.name: Rob Yates

-KxNO5yD9x2kWO4mmMYE.description:
I'm Mum to Emily, Mathilda, Verity, Noah and Adam.

I've been coming to Gateway for well over 10 years. I love Gateway!

I was part of the Gateway Toddlers team for 10 years and I now lead Acomb Babies along with Sue Downing and Suzanne Cooke.

Outside of Gateway I enjoy the gym, books, and time with family and friends.
-KxNO5yD9x2kWO4mmMYE.name: Sara Sweetman

-L8mDHDQoDkVImdjMdlC.description: I’m Miriam, and I lead a wonderful Lifegroup with my friend Kate. Gateway has been my home since my student days and I love helping with the youth work and organising monthly socials for 20-30 year olds. I’m passionate about helping others to connect with God and grow deeper in their knowledge of Him and the Bible. Global mission is also very much on my agenda – I long to see the nations find hope in Jesus. My other interests include: nursing, travel, hanging out with family and friends, going the gym, and most importantly...chocolate!
-L8mDHDQoDkVImdjMdlC.name: Miriam Howson

-L9AEnwD_R1ASKjv3tqI.description: Hi. My name is Kate and I lead a life group with Sarah Curry. I have been at Gateway since 2015 and feel very settled here. I am an archaeologist, which basically means I play in mud all day! At Gateway I am also a CAP Money coach, helping to run money management courses, and I help organise @ - the 20's and 30's social group. I enjoy reading, watching sport and tv, and spending time with friends and family.
-L9AEnwD_R1ASKjv3tqI.name: Kate Langley

-L9jgbF_XW1LlZOpeG0f.description: I'm Lucy den Braber married to Alex den Braber and have three beautiful children called Rebecca (10yrs), Oliver (8yrs) and Samuel (3yrs). I've been coming to Gateway for about four years and can honestly say it has become my home and I've made some amazing friends and new family through the congregation. Within Gateway, I work as a Debt Coach for CAP. I love meeting new people and having the amazing opportunity of being able to bring Jesus into their lives as well as practically giving people solutions to get out of debt. Together with my husband Alex I lead a Lifegroup. I'm also part of the kids team and help out two Sundays a month worshipping and playing with the vast amount of children that are a part of our Gateway family. On Thursday afternoons I help lead in SHINE, an after school club, which continues to amaze me as I see God work in the lives of so many children. At home I'm a busy mum and I love meeting up for coffee and cake. I also love reading, walking and going camping in our very beat up "vintage" caravan.
-L9jgbF_XW1LlZOpeG0f.name: Lucy den Braber

-L9jxL-AHk2Jqh4LY8EK.description: My wife Lucy and our two children, Rebecca and Oliver, moved from east London to Acomb in 2010 before having our third child, Samuel, in 2014. I commute to work in Leeds and often coax colleagues into jogging along the canal during lunch. When I'm not a taxi driver for the family you may also see me jogging around York engrossed in some podcast. At Gateway I lead a Lifegroup with Lucy.
-L9jxL-AHk2Jqh4LY8EK.name: Alex den Braber

-LADh-V_UurBM8YJPfEo.description: My wife, Tineke, and I moved to York in 2016. I've spent my life teaching English as a Foreign Language, including 20 years in Africa, and we're now enjoying retirement. I've been involved with the Fairtrade movement for a long time, and I also work with BookAid, collecting Bibles and Christian books for developing countries. The Food Bank and Friends International also occupy some of my time. And supporting Nottingham Forest (twice European champions) has been a preoccupation since childhood.
-LADh-V_UurBM8YJPfEo.name: Derryck Orridge

-LADjliIAO-6Dg9s0pM6.description: I'm from the Netherlands, and I was a teacher there, before moving to Zambia. I met Derryck there, and we married and eventually moved to Zimbabwe, before coming to England and settling in Whitby. After a few years working with WEC International in Buckinghamshire, we moved to York, and joined Gateway. I spend one day a week working with Family Matters, and I am also involved with Friends International, maintaining our link with overseas students. I have 3 little grandsons, and that's brought a new and very welcome dimension to our lives.
-LADjliIAO-6Dg9s0pM6.name: Tineke Orridge

-LOT8Q7kGjF32uxtwnla.description: My name is Karen Munro and I moved up to York in 2014 with my husband, Peter. I work from home as a medical writer during the week. In my spare time I enjoy jogging, pottering around my allotment, playing board games, and relaxing with a cup of tea! Here at Gateway I lead the team of people who provide refreshments on Sunday mornings.
-LOT8Q7kGjF32uxtwnla.name: Karen Munro

-LOTAAlcWjcgP-RBB7UM.description: Hi. My name is Sarah and I lead a Lifegroup with Kate Langley. I have been at Gateway for about 5 years and love being a part of this Church family. I am a primary school teacher and enjoy the challenge that teaching 4 year olds brings! In Gateway, I also help Kate organise @ the 20’s-30’s social group, help lead our wonderful group of youth and can sometimes be found running the info point desk – if you are new to Gateway or have any questions come and say hi!
-LOTAAlcWjcgP-RBB7UM.name: Sarah Curry

-LOTBIjMfSWd9qJ_rL-6.description: I'm married to Mark and have two daughters Lucy and Alice. I'm the Finance Director for a Telecoms Company, which Mark and I run together. I enjoy being outdoors, gardening or riding my bike. On a chilly evening I'll be by the fire with my crochet.
-LOTBIjMfSWd9qJ_rL-6.name: Sarah Mills

-LOTCDXUKh3fkYD4kwat.description: I’m Kirsty, wife to Phil and mummy to Cerys, Toby and Duncan. I’ve worked for a Christian charity based in Bradford for over 10 years and am passionate about equipping and empowering the local church to turn faith into action and see lives transformed. podcastinfo.author: Gateway Church
podcastinfo.name: Gateway Church - Weekly Sermons
podcastinfo.subtitle: Our weekly Sunday sermons from Gateway Church, York, UK
podcastinfo.summary:
Our church community is made up of people of all ages and from all walks of life. We're based in York (UK) and we define our mission in three words: KNOWING, GROWING and GOING.

Our first priority is to KNOW God - not just knowing things about him, but following him in a life-giving relationship and experiencing his empowering presence. God wants us to GROW in our faith, and he wants us to grow together as a church community. Both happen as we love and serve one another with the gifts he gives us. Becoming a disciple of Jesus changes our relationship with the world. God calls us to join him in his mission to GO and reach every person with the good news that Jesus is now King. Just as Jesus was sent into the world, he now sends us.

-K4EGwo0zPjGTc-WB3Et.name: Together (Women's Breakfast video)

-K8FA4A-dMjVyT37em8n.article:
A few months back I preached a sermon about the book of Psalms in the Bible. I made a passing remark about something which since then has stuck with me and continues to challenge me today.

Psalms 120-134 are commonly known as the Songs (or Psalms) of Ascent. It is widely believed that these songs were collated together for a particular use. There are a number of schools of thought on what exactly this particular use was, but one suggestion is that they were songs to be sung as the Jewish people travelled to the temple in Jerusalem three times each year for the major feasts/festivals. Jerusalem is on a hilltop, so these would be sung as they ascended towards the city.

I love that image of groups of people worshipping together on their journey to the temple. People would be travelling in from every direction, from their homes around the nation towards the capital city. And on the road they would sing together these songs. There is a building, a crescendo to these songs. It's a way of preparing and focussing hearts and minds before they gather in the temple.

The reason this challenges me is that I have found that I often only really prepare my heart for a Sunday service if I have a role to play - if I'm preaching or leading a meeting or running a youth group. On a Sunday when I don't have a specified role I can sometimes turn up having never prepared or focussed my heart and mind.

I'm trying to change this and every Sunday trying to set aside some time to prepare my heart and listen to God. It's an unhelpful state of mind to turn up believing that I don't have a role to play if I'm not on a rota. Whenever we worship together we're all participants, we all have a role. God may prompt me to bring something to the meeting, a word, an encouragement. He may want me to share this from the front or he may want me to share this with an individual.

And there's just something powerful about coming to a church service with my heart ready to worship. When I preached that sermon about the Psalms I remember asking the question "What songs do you sing on the way to church?"

We can choose to come to church unprepared and hope that others will lead us into a place of worship, or we can prepare our hearts before the service so when we gather we are ready to praise and worship him.

It could be a few minutes reading the Bible on a Sunday morning, or it could be as simple as listening to a worship song as we get ready or travel to church.

The question is this... What songs will you sing on the way to church? How will you prepare your heart before coming to worship with others on a Sunday morning?
-K8FA4A-dMjVyT37em8n.name: What songs do you sing on your way to church?
-K8FA4A-dMjVyT37em8n.summary: Caleb challenges us to think about what we do in preparation for our Sunday worship gatherings.

-KQfOUidvFSijlDIOoI0.article:
If this is your first time hearing about Newday let me explain what it is. Newday is a huge young people’s christian event, bringing around 6,000 people together from churches in the UK and in Europe, to engage with the word of God, worship together and either start their friendship or build their friendship with Jesus.

However, I know Newday is so much more than this. Over the week friendships strengthen during; trips to get milkshakes, playing games together, working together in tasks such as preparing meals or washing up, having late night conversations and praying for one another. At Newday people have amazing encounters with God, including healing (physical and emotional) and experiences of being filled with the Holy Spirit.

This year was my second year at Newday and I feel that I’ve learnt how to interpret the God’s word and apply it to my life, therefore developing my connection with God and with this, uncovering a little bit more of God’s plan for me.
-KQfOUidvFSijlDIOoI0.name: Our time at Newday
-KQfOUidvFSijlDIOoI0.summary: Farren shares her thoughts on our time at Newday!

-KQfQIX1otlzsDFWmrr-.article:
Over 10 days in the middle of August we took a group of 9 young people and 3 leaders to Budapest, Hungary for a mission trip working with Youth With A Mission. We had a brilliant time and the young people threw themselves into everything we threw at them! From prayer walks to cleaning, from sharing testimonies and singing in public squares to praying with homeless people, it was so encouraging to see our young people put their faith into action and love and serve people.

A particular highlight for me was seeing our team interact with a group of Roma gypsy children at a project we visited on two different days. When we first arrived the kids and our team were very unsure of one another, but by the end we had laughter, face-painting and piggy-back rides. Thank you so much to everyone who prayed for us and supported this trip financially - it really was of huge benefit to everyone involved.
-KQfQIX1otlzsDFWmrr-.name: Budapest Mission Trip
-KQfQIX1otlzsDFWmrr-.summary: Caleb shares his thoughts on our time in Budapest

-KQfSU2HZcqhsudj2ZVa.article:
Over the Bank Holiday weekend a bunch of us spent a wonderful weekend attending 'Devoted'. The weather was 'mixed' to say the least and our shared meal on Saturday was under cover as torrential rain came to add to the general excitement!

The worship led by Lou Fellingham and her band was amazing - spirit filled and prophetic. The day time seminars were thought provoking and inspirational, ranging from studies on Mark’s Gospel, workshops on marriage and parenting and an inspiring and challenging set of sessions about living Life in the Spirit. On Saturday night we had some incredible teaching by Tope Koleoso and we learnt about the exciting work of Christ Central churches across the world. The children also had a wonderful time encountering God and having fun in the high quality kids work.

The whole weekend provided a great set of memories, a boost to our walks with God and a lot of food for thought. Thank you to all who made it happen.

media.name: How could a good God send people to hell?

-KUHLNrd96zqPxr5OegB.name: How could a good God send people to hell?
-KUHLNrd96zqPxr5OegB.summary: John Wilson faces the difficult question of how a good God can send people to hell.

-KUWNzWp1gkDCmtG7oOw.article:
If God is good why does he seem so angry?

(Edited transcript of talk by John Wilson on 091016 – Part 1 of series “Is God Good?”)

If there’s one popular image of God it has to be him striking someone with lightning for doing something he disapproves of. Behind the cartoon images is a perception that God is generally angry and inclined to lash out, so you don’t want to get on the wrong side of him. We even refer to severe weather events as “acts of God.”

If we’re honest, even those of us who are card-carrying Christians, at times, can find doubts creeping in. When we read certain passages in the bible, when we look at the terrible things going on in the world, or more particularly when we face painful situations in our own lives, we begin to wonder “Is God really good?”

Over the next 3 weeks my aim is to come at this topic from a number of angles. This morning I want to look at God as portrayed in the Old Testament.

Let me start with a quote from a popular book:

‘The God of the Old Testament is arguably the most unpleasant character in all fiction: jealous and proud of it; a petty, unjust, unforgiving control freak; a vindictive, bloodthirsty ethnic cleanser; a misogynistic, homophobic, racist, infanticidal, genocidal, filicidal, pestilential, megalomaniacal, sadomasochistic, capriciously malevolent bully.”

(Richard Dawkins – The God Delusion).

Other critics of God might be more measured in how they express it, but this is increasingly the mainstream view in our society – that the God portrayed in the OT is definitely NOT good, and has no place in the 21st Century. Apparently now we’re in the 21st C people are so much wiser and better equipped to judge what’s good than we were previously.

There are numerous passages in the OT that people use to support that view. If we’re honest, some of those passages can leave us feeling uncomfortable too.

However, we should resist any reading of the bible that sets up a contrast between a mean OT God and a much nicer NT God. Like God underwent some kind of personality change. There’s only one God, who reveals himself as Father, Son and Holy Spirit.

In the OT, God is known by various names and titles. But his personal name – the name he invited his people to call him by – is YAHWEH. Traditionally it was rendered in English as Jehovah, but more accurately it is YHWH (no vowels). In modern English bibles “the LORD”. It’s always seemed unfortunate to me that we’ve substututed a title for his name. A name is more personal. It lends itself better to relationship. And that’s what God invites people into – both in the OT and in the NT.

However The OT describes Yahweh as being slow to anger. It’s so much part of his character that he includes it in his name when he introduces himself to Moses on Mount Sinai:

The LORD, the LORD, the compassionate and gracious God, slow to anger, abounding in steadfast love and faithfulness.” (Exodus 34:5-6)

The Hebrew word we translate as “steadfast love” is hesed. It can also be translated as lovingkindness, love or mercy. The closest we come is perhaps the love of a devoted parent to a child from infancy to adulthood and beyond. Or the tender love of a husband and wife husband over decades of marriage. It’s not a word to be used lightly.

The word occurs 251 times in the OT, and in the vast majority of instances it’s used to describe God. His abundant or overwhelming hesed, or steadfast love, endures forever.

SO…is God angry at times? Yes. Is he loving? Yes. Anger and love are not mutually exclusive. Anger about a breakdown in relationship is often the first step towards forgiveness and reconciliation. Anger at injustice and oppression are often the first step to doing something about it. An absence of anger can be a symptom of indifference rather than a lack of love.

Clearly we haven’t time to cover all the problem passages in the OT, so what I’d like to do this morning is look at just one incident where God is angry, and what I hope to show you is that things are not always what they appear. Every incident is part of a bigger story – the story of God’s steadfast love in restoring a fallen human race to its original glory as his image – bearers.

That redemptive purpose sometimes requires radical action on God’s part.

But remember that God is no armchair general sacrificing men and women in pursuit of some grand strategic objective. He’s the king who comes to rescue his people and to give his life on the cross as a ransom. Every story in the OT anticipates this amazing demonstration of God’s steadfast love.

With that in mind let’s look at a specific story from the OT that is often referred to by those who take a dim view of God:

Uzzah and the Ark - 2 Samuel 6:1-10

This is one of those passages that people read and say ‘I don’t want anything to do with a God like that.Maybe you’ve felt that yourself.

Just to be clear, the ark in question here isn’t the one that Noah built for sailing in, but the one that The Lord instructed Moses to make on the journey to the promised land.

The word we translate ark simply means a chest or a box. (Picture)

It was about 4 feet long by about 2.5 feet wide and high, overlaid with gold, and on top was a slab of gold known as the mercy seat, with 2 angels spreading their wings over it.

The ark was the most important piece of furniture in the tabernacle. It was the centrepiece in the Holy of Holies – The most Holy Place.

Here’s a floor plan of the tabernacle. And there in the Holy of Holies, over the ark appeared the shekinah – the glory of God; the infinitely holy, brilliant presence of the transcendent God.

There was no more sacred object in the history of Israel than the ark.

Some years before this incident we just read about, the ark had been captured by the Philistines. The sons of the High priest had decided to take the ark into battle, because they thought that would assure Israel of victory. They were treating it like some kind of lucky charm. And the Philistines defeated them and captured the ark.

However they quickly realized it was a very dangerous thing to have around and sent it back to Israel. But the Israelites didn’t know what to do with it either, and for 20 years it had stayed in the house of a man called Abinadab, and his 2 sons Ahio and Uzzah, who feature in our story.

Meanwhile, David had become King, and established Jerusalem as his capital. And now he wanted to bring the ark there. He wanted God to be at the centre of their national life. But David had a personal motivation too in wanting to bring the ark to Jerusalem. He was a man who depended on God. Psalm 27:

“One thing I ask of the Lord, this is what I seek: that I may dwell in the house of the LORD all the days of my life, to gaze upon the beauty of the LORD and to seek him in his temple.

For in the day of trouble he will keep me safe in his dwelling; he will hide me in his tabernacle and set me high upon a rock. Then my head will be exalted above the enemies who surround me; at his tabernacle will I sacrifice with shouts of joy.”

David understood the pressures that came with being king – he knew that if he was going to make it he needed God’s presence - spiritual reality. This is what the ark represented.

Isn’t it the same with you and me? That if we’re going to live our lives as God intends then we need spiritual reality. It’s one thing to know in your head that God loves you. But only when his love is real in your heart can you begin to live freely and confidently. Secure in your identity as a child of God. Not driven by the need to prove yourself or by what other people think.

David knew that if he had spiritual reality then his joy wouldn’t be subject to his circumstances. Don’t you and I want that too? The face of God, the presence, the glory?

That was what the ark represented. But there was a problem. The ark was a dangerous thing to be around.

As I said, The Philistines found that out the hard way. When they put it in the temple of their god Dagon, they came back in the morning and found Dagon lying face down before the ark. They stood him up again but when they came back he was back on his face again, this time with his head and hands broken off.

In every town they took the ark, people were afflicted with tumours.

Before long they put it on a cart and sent it back to Israel. It turned up in the village of Beth Shemesh and the people said “oh look, the ark, let’s take a peek inside”. And 70 of them died.

And so it ended up in the house of Abinadab. And now, 20 years later, David shows up with 30,000 men to get it.

It’s a massive, festive occasion –cf Nottinghill carnival – big parade, marching band. People are excited. At one point the cart wobbles a bit, and instinctively Uzzah, walking alongside, reaches out to steady the ark. When I read that I can easily imagine myself doing the same thing, can’t you? But God is angry and strikes Uzzah dead. The parade comes to a halt. The band stops playing. People are stunned. David is angry. He thought he was trying to do the right thing, and God goes and ruins the occasion with what could easily appear to be some kind of petulant display of anger.

People have answered that question in a number of ways.

1. Uzzah died because there was some kind of force field around the ark that zapped him. Cool idea but owes more to Indiana Jones than the bible.

2. It was God’s response to disobedience and lack of respect.

This is more credible. God had given them very clear rules about how they were to transport the ark.

It had to be covered – not made into a public spectacle

It had to be carried – not loaded onto a cart. There were rings on the side for poles

It couldn’t be touched

Every one of those rules was disregarded.

To our contemporary, casual sensibilities, Yahweh’s concern with ark transportation might seem a bit OCD. But the rules were there to protect people.

It’s a bit like handling radioactive material. There are very strict rules about how to transport it, for the very good reason that if you’re careless, people die. The guidelines for handling the ark were there to protect people.

Sinful people can’t just wander into the presence of a holy God any way they feel like it. It’s dangerous.

Also, handling the ark in the way they did not only involved disobedience, it was hugely disrespectful.

Remember what the ark represented – it wasn’t just a box – it represented the presence of God. Essentially, it was like a litter – a kind of throne for a king to be carried on. (picture). You see the same thing in other ancient cultures like China and Egypt.

It was a mark of honour. They would NEVER have transported a dignitary or royal person on a cart.

Imagine if the queen came to visit York and the city council asked her to jump in the boot of someone’s car. That’s basically what Israel was doing with God.

So is that what this is all about? Because they didn’t follow the rules and show Him respect, God was angry and Uzzah paid the price?

That’s how this story is sometimes applied. God expects our obedience and respect and if you don’t shape up he’s going to be angry with you.

My own view is that this story is more about what God does for us rather than about what we’re supposed to do for God.

The cause of Uzzah’s death was not just that he broke the rules and or showed disrespect or indifference. All those things were in play. But they were symptoms rather than the cause. If they had been the cause, then why weren’t they ALL struck down the moment they lifted the ark onto the cart? Uzzah couldn’t have done it on his own.

And what about DAVID? He was the guy in charge. When a team’s playing badly who gets fired? Not the players – the manager!

What I believe the story of the ark highlights is the CHASM between sinful man and a holy God. A chasm that we can’t bridge with religion or morality or even our devotion. A chasm that even God can’t bridge with just a snap of his fingers. Sin has to be paid for. He can’t just say “let bygones be bygones”. There has to be a sacrifice. An atonement. There’s a debt that has to be paid. If we don’t see that chasm, if we don’t realize it’s there, then there is no hope for us.

BECAUSE ONLY WHEN WE’VE SEEN THE CHASM CAN WE SEE THE CURE.

Uzzah thought like all religious people think - I’m doing God a favour here.”

He thought he was a good person – that he could manage God – give God a hand. Maybe growing up with the ark in his house had led him to see himself as God’s caretaker.

This attitude is lethal. And God in his mercy wanted to give them a wake up call – especially to David.

How does this apply to us?

As I see it, it’s a story about the futility of our self-righteousness. Don’t make the mistake of thinking you can manage God. By being a good person, by holding the “right beliefs”, by reading your bible, by being devoted.

In trying to protect the ark Uzzah seemed noble and religious. But our best attempts to be good are utterly insufficient to bridge the chasm between us and God. The only thing that bridges the chasm is the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ.

The story of Uzzah points us to the New Covenant where the ark that was too holy to touch becomes the symbol of God’s grace. In Jesus, we are made holy. NOW, You can approach God with confidence and without fear.

The last part of the story illustrates what needs to happen.

Step 1. We need to see the chasm. When Uzzah was struck down, David was shocked. He saw the chasm. He said (verse 9) “How can the ark of the LORD ever come to me?” How can I ever experience God’s presence?

He’s wrong – but he’s a lot closer than he was when he didn’t realize the chasm was there.

Step 2. We need to see the cure – God doesn’t just want you to know the bad news – that you’re more wicked than you ever imagined. He also wants you to see the good news – that you can be more loved and accepted than you ever dared to hope.

In the tabernacle, there was only one man who was permitted to enter the Holy of Holies where the glory of God was present above the ark. That was the High Priest. If anyone else entered they would die. And even he could enter only on one day each year, on the day of atonement, which as it happens, falls next Wednesday.

He went in for a specific purpose – to atone for the sins of the people. This he did by sprinkling the blood of the sacrifice on the mercy seat.

For the chasm to be bridged, for sins to be atoned for, there has to be a sacrifice.

Why? If God wants to forgive us, why couldn’t he just forgive? Why does it need a sacrifice?

Because forgiveness always requires suffering. If you don’t see that it’s because you’ve never been wronged very badly. If you’ve ever been hurt very badly you feel there’s an injustice, a debt to be paid. You can’t just shrug it off. You can do one of two things. You can make THEM pay, in which case they suffer. Or you can forgive, in which case YOU choose to absorb the suffering. Forgiving someone who has badly wronged you is a painful process. It leads to life, but it’s hard.

You can either make them pay, and evil spreads. Or you can pay the price yourself, and evil is overcome. If that’s true of us, then how much more will God have to suffer in order to forgive us – our disobedience and disrespect and indifference, and all the sin in this world.

And on the Cross, that’s exactly what we see happening. What we do in a small way internally and subjectively, each time we choose to forgive, God does objectively and cosmically on the cross. He suffers for the sins of the world. There was no way round it. He couldn’t just say “Oh let bygones be bygones.” Someone has to pay.

The ark with its mercy seat was a shadow of what was to come, a signpost pointing forward to the atonement that Christ would bring about through his once-for all sacrifice on the cross.

That’s why the book of Hebrews tells us that the tabernacle and everything in it is a shadow, a signpost pointing to eternal realities. And that Jesus, the Son of David, our great High Priest, entered the true Holy of Holies on our behalf - not with the blood of animals but with by His own blood – to atone for our sin. Not once a year but once for all - forever.

And because of that the writer of Hebrews says this:

“Let us then approach the throne of grace with confidence, so that we may receive mercy find grace to help us in our time of need.” Hebrews 4:16

The throne of grace is a reference to the mercy seat on the ark.

Uzzah couldn’t touch the symbol of God’s presence without dying. But, in Christ, you and I can come into God’s presence and live. The chasm has been bridged.

That’s the gospel. That’s what was at stake in the story of Uzzah and the ark. And that’s what David came to see.

After 3 months he heard that the LORD had blessed the household of Obed Edom, where the ark was being kept. And so once more he went to bring it back to Jerusalem.

Only this time he had it carried by the poles, not loaded onto a cart. And when they had taken six steps, he stopped and made a sacrifice. He’d seen the chasm. And he’d seen the cure.

And the story says that he danced before the Lord. That wasn’t something kings were supposed to do. They were supposed to behave in a dignified way. He was criticized for doing it. But he didn’t care what people thought. Now he knew God’s grace; God’s presence.

When you’ve seen the chasm, and seen the cure, then joy comes into your life. Security. Confidence in your identity. There’s nothing you need to prove.

That’s the difference between a religious person and a gospel-transformed person. If your relationship with God is about you trying hard and hoping God will see that and come out to bat for you, there’s no joy in that.

But if it’s that God took the suffering upon himself to satisfy the need for justice and bridge the chasm so you can enjoy the presence of a holy God. And he did that for you…that changes everything.

What an incredible blessing and privilege it is to come to the very throne of grace – the mercy seat – without fear - because of the work of Christ on your behalf!

The story of Uzzah is part of the story of the steadfast love of a good God.

-KbyHDkaSsQt4XaSaAhk.article:
This Sunday we launched a new initiative, with the aim to see Gateway become a church that is both deep and wide - having deep relationships and friendships, and growing in confidence in sharing our faith with others.

We made an invitation to all those present to come on a journey with us, a journey shaped around 4 practices that we believe will help to create a deep and wide church.

BLESS

We aim to bless one Gateway, and one not-yet-Christian individual/family each week.

EAT/DRINK

We aim to share hospitality with one Gateway, and one not-yet-Christian individual/family each week.

LEARN

We aim to have 15 minutes in a chair daily, spending quality time with God.

LEVEL UP

We aim to take the conversation up a level with one Gateway person and one not-yet-Christian each week.

If you weren't able to be there on Sunday, I highly recommend that you listen to the launch talk above.

We're seeing Lifegroups as the primary way of encouraging and challenging one another to live out these practices and see them become habits. If you're not yet in a Lifegroup and would like to be, please contact the office as soon as possible.

-L2KfjppmyWSY9yD4bhX.article:
In our family we've usually taken all of our Christmas decorations down before we've even hit New Year's Eve. I know we're supposed to leave them up until the 12 days of Christmas have gone, but when the shops have had decorations up for 3 months already, I'm ready to move on from Christmas and get ready for January to start.

It felt a little odd to start the reading plan on January 1st with the nativity story, having in my mind already moved on from "Christmas mode" into "January mode". But I'll admit it, I actually enjoyed it. Sometimes, even as Christians, we're guilty of packing our teaching, reflecting and celebrating of Christmas away for the year along with our Christmas decorations, only to revisit it again the following December. We've linked the Christmas story with December to an extent that we don't dwell on the incredible nativity story during the other 11 months of the year.

But the Christmas story is as relevant in January or June as it is in December.

John says, "The Word became flesh and made his dwelling among us."1 Matthew recounts Isaiah prophesying hundreds of years earlier that the son born to a virgin would be called Emmanuel (which means 'God with us')2. The Word didn't become flesh and make his dwelling among us for December, then go and make his dwelling elsewhere in January. God didn't become Emmanuel and stay with us for a few days before deciding he had had enough of us.

God is for life, not just for Christmas (I couldn't resist!).

Every month of the year, we can celebrate the God who loved us so much that he literally stepped into our story, becoming fully human, walking with us, teaching us and ultimately dying for us before conquering death and rising to new life. The first Christmas kicked off a new chapter in the story of God and mankind. From that point on he would be "God with us" in a new way. This continues today.

God is with us.

Every moment of every day.

Every month of the year.

I don't know about you, but one of my greatest challenges is to live in the awareness of him being with us at all times.

A team of us from various churches in Acomb do a weekly assembly in one of the local primary schools. We act out (badly) a different story from the Bible each week. We do the assemblies for children in 4 different year groups, and it takes us about 2 years to get through all the stories in our Storybook Bible. Once we've finished the Bible, we just start again from the beginning. What this means is that we rarely have the stories at the "right" time of the year. This year we were acting out the Christmas story at Easter, and the Easter story at Christmas. Again, it felt a little jarring to do this. And certainly, some of the teachers found it amusing! But for me, it was incredibly powerful to help the children join the dots between the Jesus who came as a baby and the Jesus who died and rose again.

My hope and prayer is that for some of those children, we're able to help them see the significance of Jesus beyond what they have neatly packaged to them during the "right" times of the year.

My hope and prayer for all of us is that we'll continue to allow the Christmas story to transcend December; that we'll remember every day of the year that God stepped into our world to be Emmanuel - God with us.

1. John 1:14

2. Matthew 1:23 quoting Isaiah 7:14

You can download a copy of the Reading Plan here.

-L2txBjkmt4Sbcr1Ar2Y.article:
As a stay at home parent of small children I must admit that finding time to read my bible can be challenging. After a long day of running around after my active boys, running a household, satisfying my various volunteer roles, and keeping up to date on friends and family, sitting down in silence with a book is more likely to result in an unplanned nap rather than some deep reflections on the Word!

This is where the reading plan has been invaluable, the motivation of knowing that the rest of the church are all reading along with me and experiencing these verses at the same time has spurred me on to carve out a smidge more time every day, and muster up a tiny bit of extra energy to devote myself to the Word. I’m more grateful than ever to be a part of a faith-filled, bible-based church.

The beautiful thing about the verses we have been reading this week is that we have been experiencing Jesus in action. We sit and listen to the sermon on the mount. We see him feed the multitude with just a few loaves and fish. We have sailed with him on the Sea of Galilee, been to dinner in the house of Matthew the tax collector with all his sin loving buddies, walked through the towns and met people with him, and been privileged to have witnessed his miracles.

What has stood out to me the most has been the absolute faith of some of the people Jesus encountered. The army officer (Luke 7 & Matthew 8) who wanted his servant healed. The synagogue leader, Jairus (Mark 5, Matthew 9 & Luke 8), whose daughter was gravely ill. The woman with the issue of blood (Matthew 9, Mark 5 & Luke 8). These people had not yet themselves experienced a miracle, but in their need they reached out to Jesus with complete confidence and faith that he could help. I think sometimes it can be easy to forget that we serve a supernatural God, the God of miracles. We serve the same God as the army officer, as Jairus, and this woman. It can be easy, in the midst of trial or worry, to wrack our brains for the best solutions we can find, to fret and worry, to consult the counsel of friends and family, or to look online for answers or support. But what the bible teaches us is that we should do everything we can to bring our problems to Jesus.

I’ve been a Christian for 15 years now, and I couldn’t even tell you the number of times that I have been discussing a worry or problem with a friend and they’ve asked, “Have you prayed about it?” and I hadn’t. Why prayer isn’t always my first response to worry, I’m not sure, but I can only say how grateful I am that we serve a loving God who forgives my mistakes, sends me wise Christian friends to counsel me, and wants to heal my heart and help me with my worries if only I will have faith in him.

You can download a copy of the Reading Plan here.

-L3Son7h6QPkE3JdVefu.article:
The four accounts of Jesus' life that we read in the Bible are packed with Jesus' teaching; in some ways they're like an instruction manual for life. Jesus’ teaching, while sometimes hard to hear, can inspire us with a vision for living a great life, but can also be convicting when we don’t live up to it.

I must admit the repetition of the disciples' differing accounts of Jesus’ life in this week's readings were a struggle at first. However, by the end of the week I was enjoying spotting the slight differences – imagining what type of people the disciples were by the bits and pieces they remembered or had omitted.

These readings were all from the significant time when Jesus’ death was becoming closer and closer, which he predicts to his disciples. However, I love the fact that Jesus focuses on instructing his followers and not wallowing in his own self-pity or thoughts. He takes the time to instruct us on ‘life’, and how we can be saved. Telling us ‘do not worry’ as God will provide (Luke 12), and giving guidance on how we can ‘inherit eternal life’ (Luke 18:18).

Not only does Jesus not focus on himself, he makes sure we can prepare for what is to come, for our own salvation. There’s the instruction on several occasions not to build up worldly wealth, but instead to share it (Luke 12), as well as the repetition of the ten commandments – not to murder, steal, commit adultery, as well as the disciples' questions on divorce. As well as these practical rules, we also see Jesus reminding us to be humble - that those who ‘exalt themselves will be humbled, and those who humble themselves will be exalted’ (Luke 18:14). As well as being humble, we are also called to serve (Matthew 20), just as Jesus did when he walked the earth.

These day-to-day instructions include a reminder from Jesus that prayer also plays an important role in everyday life, and that ‘if you believe, you will receive whatever you ask for in prayer' (Matthew 21:22). Not only was Jesus giving us the preparation for how to live a Godly life, but he was also reminding us of the constant need for communication with God and unfaltering belief in him.

I was really struck this week by the large amount of instruction given by Jesus, but extremely humbled that amid his own impending death he wasn’t focusing on himself, but giving his followers the commandments to attain eternal life; not just worrying over possessions and wealth, but living a life pleasing to God and one that reflects all that God has in store for us.

I’ve come to the last day of these readings and have been thoroughly challenged about being humble, servant-hearted and preparing for what is to come.

Is there an area of your life where you need to apply his instruction more? Maybe worry less, or dedicate more time to prayer? Whatever these readings have provoked in you, start by giving them to God and asking for his guidance.

You can download a copy of the Reading Plan here.
