-L40_Pak1nwXVguyUK9D.article:
Reading the chapters set out for us this week, I have been struck by how radical Jesus is and how uncomfortable and difficult it must have been to be around him.

His incredible miracles, his understanding of the needs of those who were looking for a shepherd and his ability to communicate the heart of his Father understandably earned him a large following. However, his uncompromising words, strange parables and quite frankly swingeing insults (take a look at the 7 Woes) caused others to question and fall away or, if you were one of the ‘insulted’, to become his enemy.

These chapters outline the time in Jesus ministry when he experienced mounting opposition. However, he didn’t tone things down to make life easier for himself or for those who followed him. He continued to speak the unpalatable truth and strongly challenge the hypocrisy of the Pharisees and Sadducees.

The way he speaks at times is shocking and in this age of tolerance it would probably be deemed in a lot of Christian circles as ‘taking it just a bit too far’. However, Jesus is unafraid of the prevailing atmosphere of the times. Truth is truth is truth – and The Truth is what Jesus claimed to be.

Even the Pharisees in seeking to trap him with difficult questions said: "We know that you are a man of integrity and that you teach the way of God in accordance with the truth. You aren’t swayed by others and pay no attention to who they are." Matthew 22:16

They saw that, unlike others, Jesus was not afraid of them, and did not seem to care what they thought of him. He had one focus in his life and he never strayed from it. Knowing the truth of who he was and the eternal importance of his mission, he had resolutely decided to shed all worries about what people might think.

In contrast Peter’s story of denial is laid out in sad detail for us all to see. At this point Peter certainly hadn’t learnt the art of not being swayed by others. His fear overtook him and he denied that he even knew his friend and Lord. He was swayed in the worst way possible. However, this was not the end of the story for him. Jesus had named him ‘the Rock’ and that was who he would become because of the love and forgiveness of his Lord. His future was not defined by the failures of his past.

Jesus’ call on our lives doesn’t change even if we bottle it when the chips are down. He knows we won’t get it right all the time. He forgives us when we are swayed and we lose our focus; but not only does He forgive, He then picks us up, steadies us, points our eyes in the right direction and entrusts us with a new role in His kingdom. This amazing, uncompromising, radical Jesus chooses us to be his body here on earth.

I do not feel worthy of this calling and I realise that I am so far from understanding this radical Jesus; but I want to have faith to say with Isaiah as he prophesied about Jesus: “Because the Sovereign Lord helps me I will not be disgraced. Therefore have I set myself like flint and I know I will not be put to shame.” (Isaiah 50:7)

-L4_bF8JJlIlCce4BjYW.article:
This week’s readings took us from Jesus’ crucifixion through to the first half of Acts. I find tonnes of reassurance in the way that Jesus’ followers responded to his arrest, death and resurrection. They basically just couldn’t believe it; they couldn’t believe he was about to die, and then they couldn’t believe he’d come back to life. It took so many times for them to get it, that Jesus really was the Messiah, and that this signalled the coming of God’s kingdom.

But then there’s a bit I really loved. In Acts 1, Jesus was eating with his disciples, and he told them about the Holy Spirit. They had kept asking him, “Lord, has the time come for you to free Israel and restore our kingdom?” I imagine them to be feeling all smug because they’d finally got it, they knew what was coming next, and were impatient for Jesus to get on with it. In his reply he gives one of those answers where he turns a “no” into a “not yet.” He basically says “not to worry about the timings, leave that to God” (Acts 1:7). “BUT,” he says, “But you will receive power when the Holy Spirit comes upon you. And you will be my witnesses, telling people about me everywhere” (Acts 1:8). The disciples are expecting some immediate swooshing in of God’s restoring of the world, but Jesus tells them the next big unexpected thing about his upside-down kingdom…You. Me. Us. We’re going to be the ushering in of God’s kingdom. He’s using us to do it.

But not on our own. Our power to do that will only come when we’ve received the Holy Spirit. So then we have a load of chapters of amazing stories of the power that the apostles have, because of the Holy Spirit. Miracles. Lame people walking. Dead people coming back to life. People who had never met Jesus for themselves choosing to follow him now, because of what they were seeing in the lives of the apostles.

It is such an exciting read. But, like Caleb said in his talk this Sunday, there is a gap between what we read and what we’re experiencing in our lives, in our church today. Here are two things about that, which challenged me in this week’s readings.

Firstly, those brave, courageous, Spirit-filled followers of Jesus had their eyes firmly fixed on him, on the prize of sharing in his glory. When the angel broke them out of prison, they went straight back to preaching, knowing they’d probably end up being arrested again, because their own comfort was less important than getting the gospel-message out there. When Stephen was in serious trouble and would soon be stoned to death he “full of the Holy Spirit, gazed steadily into heaven and saw the glory of God” (Acts 7:55). His eyes were fixed on heaven, and because of what he saw there, he could face anything here on earth.

I don’t face persecution for being a Christian, but I do face some challenges, and this week I’m going to try to not let them distract me from keeping my eyes, my heart and mind fixed on Jesus.

Secondly, the apostles paid attention to the people around them. When the lame man called out to Peter and John asking for money it says in Acts 3:4 that they “looked at him intently”, before healing him. How intently or intentionally do I look at the people around me? If I don’t see people at all, I can’t expect God to answer my prayer to see them like he does. So, this week I’m aiming to be more aware of the little interactions with the people around me, to look intently, instead of just rushing past to the next job – I’m excited to see where God will lead me.

-L58h-8lEDjfvX-MwpcX.article:
I have been struck this week by Paul’s conviction, confidence and courage in the Lord to go out and preach the gospel message. This just jumps off the pages of both the third person story-telling in Acts as well as Paul’s own letters.

Conviction

It is inspiring to see the depth of Paul’s conviction that Jesus had specifically called him with a special message – to preach the gospel among the Gentiles. As Caleb shared on Sunday, the early disciples were characterised by an unshakeable belief that Jesus had risen from the dead. They had seen Him! What I find amazing about Paul is the depth of his conviction, not just in Jesus and His resurrection, but in the calling on his life. His zeal for the Gentiles is clear and whilst he goes first into the synagogues at each place, he is soon back out amongst the Gentiles. In the book of Galatians we see how incensed he is at the church there letting themselves be confused by the Jewish law and the requirement to be circumcised, when that is irrelevant for them. There is a word of warning for us all:

“Are you so foolish? After beginning with the Spirit, are you now trying to attain your goal by human effort?” Gal. 3:3

Do I have that level of conviction that what I believe is true and is true for everyone? Could I go out into a public place and defend my faith as Paul does in Athens? As Paul says: “our gospel came to you not simply with words, but also with power, with the Holy Spirit and with deep conviction.” 1 Thess 1:5

Confidence

Closely linked to Paul’s conviction is His confidence in the gospel. He would not be travelling the world preaching the gospel if he did not have the confidence that he would continue to see God move. When he has a vision of a man in Macedonia begging him to come and help them, he gets ready to go at once, confident that God had called them to preach the gospel there too (Acts 16:9-10).

In prison with Silas, and that wonderful scene of them praying and singing hymns to God, when the earthquake comes and the prison doors fly open, I sense a quiet confidence in Paul and Silas. They knew God would show up – and not to free them but to bring salvation to the jailor and his family. What faith. It is humbling to read.

Courage

In spite of the conviction he had after seeing the risen Jesus, and the confidence coming from a real gift of faith as he went on his missionary journeys, there is no doubt that all this will have required an immense amount of courage. At the prayer meeting in Leeds last month we were encouraged to pray for boldness. This is becoming a recurring theme and a natural outflow from our conviction and confidence in God.

It’s good to realise that Paul was human and did need courage to keep going:

“We had previously suffered and been insulted in Philippi, as you know, but with the help of our God we dared to tell you his gospel in spite of strong opposition.” 1 Thess 2:2

It was far from plain sailing for Paul – plenty of floggings, time in prison and generally needing to keep on the move as they fled from those who were opposing them. Was Paul tempted to give up and find a quieter, more comfortable life? Of course not! His calling was crystal clear and he was a man on a mission that no mere things like prison would distract him from.

It is inspiring to read about. How easily am I distracted by much more minor things than the risk of prison and choose to focus my thoughts and actions elsewhere rather than in the single-minded search for God’s kingdom and His righteousness? Do I know my specific calling and what I should be doing to fulfil it?

Big questions.

You can download a copy of the Reading Plan here.

Photo by Ben White on Unsplash

-L5i1lWlshRaop5wJGha.article:
This week’s readings contained a passage that I looked at regularly whilst I was living in Asia. In fact, each year I challenged all those who were just beginning their year at the mission school I was involved with to keep it in mind as they settled into life in a very different culture.

1 Corinthians 9:19-23 calls us to be willing to become like those to whom we want to preach the gospel...

“Though I am free and belong to no man,” Paul writes, “I make myself a slave to everyone, to win as many as possible. To the Jews I became like a Jew, to win the Jews. To those under the law I became like one under the law… to win those under the law. To those not having the law I became like one not having the law… to win those not having the law. To the weak I became weak, to win the weak. I have become all things to all men so that by all possible means I might save some. I do all this for the sake of the gospel.”

Living in Asia, it was very easy to see the application of that passage.

Our daily lives were taking place in a very different culture from the one we had grown up in. We were regularly offered food that wouldn’t normally appear on a British dinner table. People around us didn’t always do things the way we expected or wanted.

Yet we would eat what we were offered and make the effort to fit in with local customs, however strange and sometimes uncomfortable they might be, in order that we might have the opportunity to win people for Christ.

Now that I’m living back in my home culture, it’s easy to gloss over a Bible passage like this and assume it only applies to those called to live overseas as missionaries.

But one of God’s challenges to me this week was to apply this same passage to my situation here in my comfortable life in York.

How ready am I now to step out of my comfort zone, to “put up with anything rather than hinder the gospel of Christ” (1 Corinthians 9:12)?

What does it mean now to “become all things to all men” to win some for Christ (9:22)?

The answer will be different for each one of us.

For me that might mean something as simple as initiating a conversation with someone I don’t naturally relate to.

Or stopping my pressing tasks in order to listen to someone who is struggling and needs a listening ear.

Or taking part in an activity I might not normally choose in order to deepen a friendship.

Caleb’s sermon last Sunday focussed on living life now in the light of Jesus’ return. So it seemed very timely to start this week by reading about what “will happen when the Lord Jesus is revealed from heaven in blazing fire” (2 Thessalonians 1:7).

In that same letter, Paul reminds us of the amazing truth that when Jesus comes again, He will “be glorified in his holy people”. Just in case we haven’t quite caught hold of what that means, Paul continues: “This includes you” (1:10). God will be glorified in all those who have believed in him, including in you and in me!

Paul also tells us, “No eye has seen, no ear has heard, no mind has conceived what God has prepared for those who love him” (1 Corinthians 2:9).

If I keep those thoughts of eternity as my starting place, maybe that will help me find the strength and vision in this life to do things that I don’t find very comfortable in order to play my part in bringing some to the Lord.

You can download a copy of the Reading Plan here.

-L6Gxqa5y69mFjr-ozVi.article:
I wonder how many times you have used or heard the phrase “in hindsight...”?

We often apply this phrase to poor choices we or others have made, a reaction to events that have taken place and as a note of caution, maybe a nod towards a lesson learned.

In Paul’s writings this week, I was struck by his references to both current circumstance but also to his and others eternal destiny, often in the same breath. It led me to think about how Paul viewed the world, how he described his and others joy and troubles, but constantly in the context of “the joy that is to come” and never “in hindsight”, either reviewing anything that had happened or regretting its occurrence. Simply put, Paul’s focus was not on what had past but on what was to come, in every circumstance his viewpoint was the promise of eternal life.

This led me to think more on living life with this viewpoint, rather than in hindsight, and understanding the importance of having a "heavenly perspective”

In his letters to Corinth and Rome, Paul brings his message in the context of the troubles that he and others are experiencing but constantly encourages his readers that the focus of life and work should be on what is to come, on the promises of eternal life. Whilst he does not discount his current experiences, he recognises them for what they are and encourages his readers to live with a heavenly perspective, one that recognises the current condition of earthly circumstance but that does not then conclude that events here will dictate our destiny. He encourages us that when we accept Jesus, we are redeemed and saved at the cross and all who approach are welcomed with open arms. Furthermore, Paul writes that if we are really viewing life from this heavenly perspective rather than an earthly one, no matter what our experiences are, we will always be prompted and encouraged to share the good news of salvation and to act in a way that reflects Christ himself, because we will know that this life is fleeting and there are more important things to come.

Now forgive me, (confession time and I don’t know about how you react in these situations dear reader...), but there are days when sharing the gospel feels like the thing furthest from my thoughts during difficult times. In fact, when I think on my past troubles and trials, I often think that some of my reactions and thoughts were some of the least Godly or Salvation-worthy actions I have ever taken, and I can’t say that every time I am frustrated at my desk at work, my first reaction is to speak to one of my colleagues about Jesus’ undying love for them...

But Paul encourages us further that when we struggle and cry out to God, when we trust in him, even when we are struggling to find hope, this is when the Spirit takes hold. Whilst we may struggle with earthly troubles, with lack of things or with trying circumstances, if we allow the spirit of God to work in us at these times, this is the example of Jesus, the good news, that we share with the world. It is not a rose-coloured picture of God, of a religion or relationship for when “life is easy”, but it shows us as having a raw and honest relationship with a Father who loves us, whether we do right or wrong and whether we understand it or not. So whilst my colleagues may not hear me talk about Jesus at these times, it is my hope that they see through my actions and demeanour that he reigns in my life at ALL times, good and bad. And as Paul says, for the times when this doesn’t happen, we live under abundant grace!

I find it wonderfully encouraging that despite our weakness and failings, the Spirit will still proclaim Jesus through us, even in difficulties and troubles, and he will intercede on our behalf, calling on God for us and seeking his will... And God doesn’t stop there! As Paul writes, God continues to bless us when our hearts are aligned with his, encouraging us to share the abundance of grace, mercy and gifting that he has lavished on us, encouraging us to share it with all who are around us.

I think if these thoughts were always at the forefront of our minds, in all circumstances, the knowledge that we are saved, loved and redeemed, that when Earth is done we have the ultimate hope, the way we live would be different.

It is this heavenly perspective, the focus on what is to come, that Paul encourages us to adopt, so that we can trust in God in all circumstance, good and bad, because it is all a moment, passing in a breath before we stand in eternity before God.

And it would be easy to say “well that’s that, I’m sorted”...

But God also calls us to lead lives that are Spirit-led and Gods heart is not just to see us saved but to see as many as possible come to know him. He asks us to have a heavenly perspective that calls us to love others how he loves them.

As most of us will be aware of, the well-known evangelist Billy Graham passed away this week, his widely publicised statement that “when you read that I have died, you should not believe it because I have simply changed address” has certainly appeared more than once in my social media feeds and articles I have read. It feels only right that in the week he died, that we should be reading about having a heavenly perspective, when this was how Billy Graham spent much of his time on earth.

Mr Graham seems to have really grasped what Paul talks about in these letters, because he knew that just because his own destiny was assured, the work was not finished and God had more to do through him, by his spirit. Indeed, his heart was captured not by a selfish inward looking attitude, but on the desire to see the lost saved. He realised that even though he was already saved, that as many people as possible should have a chance to meet the same Jesus and to know the love, mercy and grace that comes from a relationship with God. Billy Graham wasn’t afraid of any perceptions of him, even when he confessed to getting things wrong, but he recognised these as fleeting troubles and did not let them obstruct his heavenly perspective, that the reason he was on earth at this time was so that he might boldly proclaim Jesus to all who would hear him.

And this is the perspective we are all called to, everyday, to not look back at what could have been avoided or might have been, but to look forward into what we know is ahead.

So the next time we feel called to despair or to lose hope, to be frustrated with earthly circumstances and troubles, it is my prayer that we will all remember Paul’s encouragements and remember to put whatever it is into perspective, because God loves us all in the here and now but there are even greater things yet to come!

You can download a copy of the Reading Plan here.

-L6prlyQ3IaBA39axoA7.article:
This week's reading is another whirlwind of both adventure and practical teachings through Paul.

To me, reading the New Testament in a chronological order has brought a new perspective and admiration of Paul's ministry in two areas which I'll touch on in turn;

  1. Paul's wreckless abandon and full submission to God in order to spread the Gospel
  2. Paul's concise and practical teachings that he brings to the church

First, we read of Paul's ordeal; being locked up, beaten up, plots to kill him, travelling towards certain danger, arrested and being shipwrecked. And he uses these life threatening and humiliating situations as opportunities to share his testimony, prophesy and proclaim the good news of Jesus. I'm not sure I would have the same composure.

God was with Paul throughout his journey. We know that God is with us too. However, unlike Paul I don't often find myself shipwrecked or chased by angry crowds. However, we can sometimes use uncomfortable, and possibly life threatening situations as an opportunity to share our faith and God's love with others. For me, recently, this has been with friends, family and colleagues plagued by ill health.

But there are many more situations where it is difficult to be honest in our faith, especially as we try to "fit in". I love how Paul ignores circumstance and cuts through these issues in his short, concise teachings and instructions to the churches and in addressing crowds.

That leads to my second point. From working in consultancy it's clear that waffle doesn't go down well. People want clear, short and succinct advice. Paul seems to communicate in this style with ease, particularly in the books of Romans and Colossians. For example:

"But now you must also rid yourselves of all such things as these: anger, rage, malice, slander, and filthy language from your lips." Colossians 3:8

Paul's teachings to the early church, the Jewish crowds, governors and officials are always clear. They're blunt. They're practical for the church and also for us as individuals. They're also 100% aligned with the message Jesus brings to us. And it is effective in growing the early church. But this doesn't mean the messages are easy... in fact they are often very challenging, especially in a society today where it can feel like what used to be extreme is now normal.

To conclude, Paul's reckless abandon to share the Gospel, no matter how bad his circumstances, is inspirational. He admits being prepared to die for the name of the Lord Jesus (Acts 21:13) and is undeterred in his ministry. But Paul is also effective in addressing an audience clearly and concisely. To have both qualities in such magnitude must only come from being filled with the Holy Spirit. To me then, Paul's ministry is an excellent example as to why we should eagerly desire the gifts of the Holy Spirit as we live to share the Gospel too.

You can download a copy of the Reading Plan here.

-L7Pcj8j7UjMoTxNWZVo.article:
Hello. Hey. Hola. G'day. Alright. Hi. Good morning. Howdy. Buenas dias. Now then.

We greet each other in all kinds of different ways.

This week we've read through Paul's letters to the churches in Ephesus and Philippi, as well as letters he wrote to Timothy and Titus. In three of them, Paul greets the church or individual with the words "grace and peace". In fact, between them, Paul, Peter and John use the greeting in 16 of the books of the New Testament. We can assume that this was a very common way to greet people in the early church.

"Grace and peace from God the Father and Christ Jesus our Saviour." Titus 1:4

They're two great words - loaded with meaning. In many ways, they summarise the Gospel - the good news. Here's how scholars have defined and explained these two simple words...

Grace (charis in the original Greek language): of the merciful kindness by which God, exerting his holy influence upon souls, turns them to Christ, keeps, strengthens, increases them in Christian faith, knowledge, affection, and kindles them to the exercise of the Christian virtues.

Peace (eirēnē in the original Greek language): security, safety, prosperity, felicity, (because peace and harmony make and keep things safe and prosperous). Of Christianity, the tranquil state of a soul assured of its salvation through Christ, and so fearing nothing from God and content with its earthly lot, of whatsoever sort that is.

So when Paul and others use "grace and peace" to greet those they're writing to, they're expressing all of the above. They're trying to encapsulate the merciful kindness, the assurance of salvation, the incredible grace and peace that is available to each and every person.

That's what they're greeting with, what they're wishing and hoping and praying for, for their readers. If Paul were writing to you today, I'd like to think he would greet you with these words. I'd like to think he'd be willing you on to understand more of the grace and peace available to you, encouraging you to receive grace upon grace, peace upon peace.

Maybe some of you today need to know more of the merciful kindness of God, maybe you need to experience more tranquillity of your soul, maybe you need to learn to be more content with your earthly lot. All of that is on offer. For you. Today.

So come to him and receive in faith.

And let's take Paul's lead in the way he greets others. Let's be people who wish more grace and more peace to those we encounter day by day, our colleagues, our friends, our neighbours. Let's allow our words and our actions to bring more grace and more peace to their lives.

You can download a copy of the Reading Plan here.

Photo by rawpixel.com on Unsplash

-L7y8P8N9thMiE8Zl9LO.article:
I don’t have a tattoo. I’ve always liked the idea of having one (despite the idea of paying some to stick a needle in my skin seeming abhorrent!), but both my mother and wife have always been against me getting one.

If I did have a tattoo it would be one word: עִמָּנוּאֵל the Hebrew for Immanuel "God with us". Hebrews begins with “The Son is the radiance of God’s glory and the exact representation of his being” (Hebrews 1:3). In the message it translates as Jesus being "stamped" with God’s nature. This concept has always been a marvel that has captivated me. The meaning of this is explored in our readings this week in the books of 1 Peter & Hebrews.

Whereas a tattoo is an outward mark, Peter in his first letter, challenges us to sort out what is inside. That we should purify ourselves and rid ourselves of all that holds us back from stepping into a full life, where we are called as chosen people to fulfil God’s mission – we are called priests.

I’ve always struggled to see myself as a priest. It’s clouded with preconceptions with the religious function (in my head I imagine an old man with a pointy hat!). I’ve had to remind myself that a priest was someone chosen by God who would fulfil his purpose, most notably by offering sacrifices. But as the readings this week show us, that was fulfilled and completed through Jesus!

What stood out to me in the readings in both books was how clear they were in what this role means for us today. Often I find people are critical of the Bible because it’s not practical. Yet we are told that the role of a priest now is to be witnesses of Jesus in word; “declare the praises of him who called you out of darkness into his wonderful light” (1 Peter 2:9) and deed; “to do good and to share with others” (Hebrews 13:16).

In the book of Hebrews it was impossible for me to miss the many mentions of Melchizedek! He is a peculiar and unique person in the Bible. Not only was he the first priest, but also a king. Jesus “was designated by God to be high priest in the order of Melchizedek” (Hebrews 5:10). What a statement to make that he is both our high priest and king!

In 1 Peter we are called out as priests. And Hebrews begins to unpack the incredible reality of who Jesus is. Yet Jesus is also described throughout Hebrews as being one of us; Jesus, fully human in every way (Hebrews 2:17). He knows us, he understands us, he is one of us. Wow! Immanuel, God with us, one of us!

As I reflected over this during the week I pictured Jesus as my big brother. He leads the way, shows me what to do and how to do it.

I might not have a physical tattoo, but I am marked, as are all of us that follow Jesus. We are marked as priests, we are marked as children of God, and as a family, we are all in this together. As the writer to the Hebrews reminds us in at the end of the letter, “Keep on loving one another as brothers and sisters. Do not forget to show hospitality to strangers.” (Hebrews 13:1-2). Let’s encourage each other, build one another up, help where we see a need, as our hearts are tattooed with Jesus, let’s make our hands and feet do his good work.

The Holy Spirit confirms this:

This new plan I’m making with Israel
isn’t going to be written on paper,
isn’t going to be chiselled in stone;
This time “I’m writing out the plan in them,
carving it on the lining of their hearts.” (Hebrews 10:15-16 MSG)

You can download a copy of the Reading Plan here.
